text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with shrimp cakes that's right i'm
going to show you one of my favorite
all-time asian seafood appetizers and
unlike the version found at most
restaurants this is going to contain
virtually no filler not that I have
anything against filler I mean heck most
of my blog posts contain 70 to 80%
filler but when it comes to shrimp cakes
the more shrimp the better and because
we're not stretching our seafood with
things like breadcrumbs not only do I
think the flavor is going to be better
but the texture as well so let's go
ahead and get started and I think you're
going to be surprised how really easy
this is as long as you have one of these
a food processor but if you don't I will
explain on the blog post how to do this
without one that will be in the 30%
that's not filler but anyway the first
and pretty much only step to this
process is to add all our ingredients to
this bowl but before you do make sure
you put the blade in otherwise it's
really hard to place in there so we will
pop in that blade and add our
ingredients which start with some raw
peeled deveined shrimp and by raw I mean
definitely not cooked all right these
little pink shrimp sort of look cooked
but they are not this recipe will not
work with cooked shrimp and above and
beyond making sure they're raw we also
definitely want them peeled and deveined
and ideally these are wild shrimp not
farmed so if you're buying a giant bag
of these at the same store you get your
tires at and they seem suspiciously
cheap be careful and then besides the
shrimp we're also going to need some
finely minced garlic as well as a whole
bunch of freshly chopped cilantro and
believe it or not you can chop up the
stems and the leaves for this we will
also toss in a little bit of brown sugar
which technically is supposed to be palm
sugar but I assumed you didn't have that
no offense and then to balance that
sweet we're going to add some heat in
two forms so we will add some sambal
which is you may know is nothing more
than a ground chili sauce and then we'll
add just a little more kick with a few
shakes of cayenne mostly for good luck
so we have our sweet and our heat but of
course we're also going to need a little
bit of saltiness so we'll do that with
some kosher salt as well as a little
touch of fish sauce which is the
expression goes smells like hell tastes
like heaven so I really hope you pick up
a bottle of that by now and then we'll
go ahead and finish up with a little bit
of tumeric which I'm adding for a little
bit of color and flavor but also for its
extraordinary health benefit
that stuff is good for everything
including libido and baldness which are
sometimes related but anyway that is it
for our shrimp cake ingredients and then
once all that's at all we need to do to
this is process it into a paste and
generally the best strategy for a
mixture like this is to do it by pulsing
on-and-off okay it's generally going to
process more evenly like this than if
you just turned it down and left it and
then what we want to do and it starts to
come together like this is stop and
scrape down the sides so we'll stop
we'll take off the top and take a
spatula and make sure there's no rogue
chunks stuck to the sides so we will
give that a little mix and then we'll
pop the top back on and continue
processing until we have a fairly smooth
paste okay but not too smooth and what
I'd look for is this when that mixture
kind of clumps up and starts moving
around the bowl in one mass that usually
tells me it's just about perfect so we
are going to stop and take a look and
that is pretty much exactly what you
should be shooting for so a fairly
smooth mixture but not a superfine puree
and then what we want to do at this
point is transfer that into a bowl
because what I like to do is pop this in
the fridge for a while because I find
these shrimp cakes much easier to make
if this mixture is very cold of course
having said that as usual if you are
super hungry and just have the wicked
munchies you could start working with
this right away but I do highly
recommend chilling it so we will
transfer that into a bowl and seal it by
pressing some plastic on the top alright
so we'll wrap that up and pop it in the
fridge for at least an hour but of
course you can go longer and then once
that mixture is nice and cold we can go
ahead and pull it out and start making
cakes and to do this what we want to do
is sprinkle down some panko or regular
bread crumbs on a plate and then we'll
scoop some hopefully equal portions down
on top of that and then we'll use the
bread crumbs to help us form these
without messing up our fingers so we
will coat that with crumbs and then form
into any shape we want except a double
helix that will be too hard and because
I'm going to fry these up in a pan I'm
just going to do some relatively thin
patties see if you were going to
deep-fry these you could make balls or
like those croquette shapes but if we do
want to pan fry these this kind of flat
patty shape will work the best and then
once our shrimp cakes have been formed
we can head over the stove to fry these
up which I'm going to do on medium-high
heat a little bit of vegetable oil
and these are only going to take a
couple minutes per side so we'll
transfer those into the pan and wait a
couple minutes and even without peeking
we can kind of see how those are getting
brown around the outside around the you
know edge so after about two minutes
when we start seeing that we'll go ahead
and flip these over and the best safest
way to do this is with two spatulas see
I'm using this significantly less
intelligent method of one spatula one
bare finger which is really not that
smart but hey I'm paid for my good looks
now my brains but anyway well flip those
over and give that other side a couple
minutes and by the way do not make the
rookie mistake of overcooking these
trying to get them all brown and crispy
okay because we used all shrimp there's
a lot of moisture in these and if we
cook them too long that's going to start
to leak out so we're only going to cook
them till they're golden brown and kind
of spring back to the touch so right
here mine we're looking perfect so I
went ahead and pull them out of the pan
and let them drain on a paper towel for
a few seconds in good news we don't have
to let these rest so as soon as we blot
it off a little bit of that excess oil
we can transfer those onto some kind of
culturally-appropriate plate and as you
can see I'll be serving mine next to a
little cucumber salad as well as a sweet
and spicy Thai style chili sauce and
then we should probably garnish with a
little bit of cilantro thereby warning
the people to candied cilantro that
their cilantro in this and that's it the
official chef Jon version of shrimp
cakes is done and while I went with kind
of a classic chili sauce here this will
work with any number of dipping sauces
so that's up to you you guys are the big
daddies of these prawn patties but
having said that I do plan on showing
you how to make that chili sauce
sometime soon but anyway let me go ahead
and grab a fork to go in for the
official taste oh and quick pro tip here
always let the excess sauce drip onto
the next bite that's just you taking
advantage of gravity but anyway dippy
sauce aside these were absolutely
amazing okay by not including the bread
crumbs in the mixture what we have here
is basically pure shrimpy goodness sweet
fragrant a little bit salty a little bit
spicy and because we pretty much use
pure shrimp and not a lot of filler not
only is it taste incredible but the
texture is so much more tender and moist
than what you get otherwise I mean look
at those shrimp juices so unless you're
getting paid to use bread crumbs I'm
really not sure why you do it any other
way
but anyway that's it how to make shrimp
cakes the all killer no filler version
as I mentioned I do plan I showed you
how to make that chili sauce sometime
soon so stay tuned for that but in the
meantime I really do hope you give these
easy and delicious shrimp cakes a try
soon so head over to food wishes calm
for all the ingredients and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
